item.title: Elder Scrolls: Skyrim Book Box Set Gets Dragon-Sized Discount
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/elder-scrolls-skyrim-book-box-set-gets-dragon-sized-discount/1100-6532360/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The world of Skyrim felt alive when players first ventured into it, and a mountain of discoverable texts helped add to its immersion. Normally, you'd have to travel all over the province to find every piece of parchment, but if you don't have that much time to do so, then you can sit back with The Skyrim Library Box Set for some quality reading. This compiles all of the collected texts into a trio beautifully illustrated hardcover books. The Skyrim Library is available at Amazon for a massive discount right now. Normally $110, it's on sale for $50.38 when you click the coupon on the store page.

The Skyrim Library: Volumes 1-3 Box Set

$50.38 with coupon (was $110)

Released back in 2017, this is a collection of three hardcover books with every piece of text from the game. The lore and historical texts are enhanced by beautiful illustrations, so if you ever wanted to have the full story on the game's factions, landscapes, and creatures, then this is a must-have for a Skyrim fan.

The other nice thing about this collection is the presentation, as the slipcase cover is designed to mimic one of the dusty old books found in a forgotten corner of Skyrim. It has a foldout cover with a giant mural of Alduin, the ferocious dragon who serves as the main villain in the game.

Elder Scrolls Book Deals (B1G1 50% Off)

  • The Elder Scrolls: The Official Survival Guide to Tamriel -- $22 ($40)
  • The Elder Scrolls Online: Tales of Tamriel - Volumes 1 and 2 -- $54 ($70)
  • The Elder Scrolls: The Official Cookbook Vol. 2 -- $19 ($35)

To add to your Elder Scrolls collection, you can also grab a few more books inspired by the games. These are all eligible for Amazon's Buy One, Get One 50% Off promotion, so there are some big savings to take advantage of here. You can pick two items from the list, and the cheapest one will have the discount applied to it.

If you're worried that you might find yourself Isekai'd into the game series, then you'll want to read through The Official Survival Guide to Tamriel for tips on how to avoid becoming dinner for a dragon. This deluxe hardcover book was only released last year and its full of handy tips and tricks for surviving perilous encounters in that land.

Lore fans can also read up on The Elder Scrolls Online, as this two-book collection offers a collection of in-game texts and exclusive artwork to pore over. When you're not reading them, these are also good-looking books to display thanks to their intricately detailed covers.

Anyone with a hunger for adventure can also check out a new volume of the official Elder Scrolls Cookbook Vol. 2.. This tome contains dozens of recipes--ranging from Troll Fat Jerky to West Weald Corn Chowder--and like other gaming-themed cookbooks, each recipe is accompanied by detailed instructions and photography to help guide you on the way toward making some Fus-Ro-Dinner.

If you love The Elder Scrolls, chances are you'd enjoy some of the fantasy novels collected in our huge roundup of books featured in the B1G1 50% off sale at Amazon.

item.title: Video Game Actor Strike Ends Today
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/video-game-actor-strike-ends-today/1100-6532363/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

After reaching a tentative agreement with video game companies to end the 11-month video game actor strike, SAG-AFTRA has now officially confirmed that the strike ends today, June 11, at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET.

All SAG-AFTRA members are now cleared to go back to work, including promotional work. The union said it will convene a special meeting on June 12 to "consider the tentative agreement." If approved, the agreement will then be sent for ratification by the union's members. This is also when the full terms of the agreement will be published.

The strike began in July 2024. The union and video game companies agreed to terms on a number of points in negotiations, but a sticking point was the matter of AI. As such, it'll be interesting to see the terms of the agreement and how it all shakes out with regards to protections against AI.

In May, Master Chief voice actor Steve Downes spoke about the importance of getting a deal that offers performers assurances that their voices can't be used by AI duplicates without their permission.

The video game companies were reported to have made what was characterized as "a key concession" on AI, but it remains to be seen what this might be. Keep checking back with GameSpot for the latest.

This wasn't the first SAG-AFTRA video game actor strike. The 2016-2017 video game actor strike also ran for about 11 months, with performers winning benefits including $100+/hour pay rates, bonus, and more.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Hong Kong Police Say Mobile Game Advocates For The Fall Of Chinese Government
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hong-kong-police-say-mobile-game-advocates-for-the-fall-of-chinese-government/1100-6532361/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

By on June 11, 2025 at 11:00AM PDT

Another chapter in China's struggle with video games and their impact on society made international news this week. Hong Kong authorities argue that Reversed Front: Bonfire promotes "armed revolution" and the overthrow of the "fundamental system" of mainland China.

"Reversed Front: Bonfire was released under the guise of a game with the aim of promoting secessionist agendas such as 'Taiwan independence' and 'Hong Kong independence,' advocating armed revolution and the overthrow of the fundamental system of the People’s Republic of China established by the Constitution of the People’s Republic of China," authorities wrote in an official statement. "It also has an intention to provoke hatred towards the Central Authorities and the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region."

Anyone who downloads, uses, or makes in-app purchases withing Reversed Front: Bonfire would violate the city's national security law, the statement later read.

The game, published by ESC Taiwan, lets players "pledge allegiance" to real-world countries and regions such as Taiwan, Hong Kong, Mongolia, Tibet, and others in order "to overthrow the Communist regime," according to the game's website. The publisher refers to the game as a work of nonfiction.

Gameplay for Reversed Front: Bonfire is basic, according to gameplay videos released by the publisher. Players control teams of several characters in turn-based combat. Those segments are broken up by story segments presented by images and dialogue.

"Any similarity to actual agencies, policies or ethnic groups of the [People's Republic of China] in this game is INTENTIONAL," the website states.

The game creator has recognized the statement from Hong Kong authorities, thanking them for introducing the game to a whole new audience of players.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Civilization 7 Deals - Get Switch 2 Version With Mouse Controls For $43
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/civilization-7-deals-get-switch-2-version-with-mouse-controls-for-43/1100-6532349/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Civilization 7 didn’t quite meet the lofty expectations of fans, but it’s still a solid empire-building strategy game worth adding to your collection. That’s especially true for console players, as you can grab Civilization 7 on PS5, Xbox, or Nintendo Switch for just $33 as part of the Woot Video Game Super Sale that runs until June 14. The PS5 and Xbox versions normally cost $70, while the Switch version is usually $60--so in all cases, you're saving quite a bit. While the Switch 2 version is not part of the deal, Switch 2 owners can grab the discounted Switch version, then upgrade to the digital Switch 2 Edition for $10 via the eShop for a total of $43 instead of the usual $70. Woot is an Amazon-owned company, meaning Amazon Prime members get free standard shipping on their orders. Woot also offers a 90-day limited warranty on all purchases.

Considering the physical Civilization 7 Switch 2 Edition is just a code in a box--it's not even a Game-Key Card--you’re not missing out on anything by grabbing the original Switch version and the digital Switch 2 upgrade instead of the Switch 2 physical edition.

Civilization 7 Switch 2 Edition supports up to a 4K resolution at 30 fps or 1080p at 60 fps when docked. The Switch 2 Edition also supports the Joy-Con 2's mouse mode, giving it a similar feel to traditional mouse and keyboard controls found on PC.

“Sid Meier's Civilization 7’s ‘one more turn’ aspect is still as engaging as ever, and I enjoyed huge portions of my playthroughs,” wrote critic Jason Rodriguez in GameSpot's Civilization 7 review, which scored an 8/10 thanks to its streamlined design that lessens micromanagement while maintaining the enthralling 4X strategy gameplay the series is known for.

Plenty of other games and gear are on sale at Woot right now, and we’ve put together a short list of our favorites below.

More Woot Video Game Super Sale Deals

  • Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth (PS5) -- $35 ($70)
  • Monster Hunter Wilds (PS5) -- $55 ($70)
  • Star Wars Outlaws: Limited Edition (Xbox) -- $25 ($70)
  • Super Mario Party Jamboree -- $45 ($60)
  • Visions of Mana (Xbox) -- $27 ($40)
  • CRKD Nitro Deck+ Nintendo Switch Grip Controller -- $45 ($80)
  • Nintendo Switch Joy-Con - Pink + Yellow -- $65 ($80)
  • Nintendo SwitchTravel Case - Tears of the Kingdom Edition -- $10 ($20)
  • PDP Victrix Pro BFG Wireless Controller (Xbox, PC) -- $130 ($180)
  • Razer Kaira Pro Wireless Gaming Headset (PlayStation, PC) -- $90 ($150)
  • Razer BlackShark V2 X (Xbox, PlayStation, Switch, PC) -- $40 ($50)
  • Tetris Micro Player Pro Mini Arcade -- $17 ($40)

item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Will Terrify From Multiple Camera Angles
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/resident-evil-requiem-will-terrify-from-multiple-camera-angles/1100-6532355/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Resident Evil Requiem will feature both first-person and third-person camera angles. Players will be able to switch between camera angles at any time within the game by pausing and changing the perspective.

Camera angles have been a huge part of Resident Evil's evolution. The original game and its sequel featured fixed camera angles, simulating security cameras viewing the action from a static position. Resident Evil 4 was the first game to switch to a dynamic, over-the-shoulder camera angle.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: The Complete Resident Evil Timeline Explained

Resident Evil 4 was a gigantic hit, both in 2005 and each subsequent time the game was re-released, and remakes of Resident Evil 2 and 3 launched with dynamic, third-person camera angles in 2019 and 2020. The Resident Evil 2 remake has sold over 15 million copies since then, making it the third-most-successful games in Capcom's history.

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard and Resident Evil Village switched to a first-person camera angle, providing more intimate scares and claustrophobic action. Resident Evil Village went on to sell over 11 million copies since launching in 2021, proving that fans would eat up the scares Capcom provided no matter the camera angle.

We played Requiem for a short time and came away with more questions than answers, leaving us hungry for the full experience. Resident Evil Requiem is set to launch on February 26, 2026.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Hearthstone Lost City Of Un'goro Card Reveal: Demon Hunter Quest Unleashes The Swarm
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hearthstone-lost-city-of-ungoro-card-reveal-demon-hunter-quest-unleashes-the-swarm/1100-6532266/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

For the next Hearthstone expansion, we're going back to the Lost City of Un'goro with another swashbuckling adventure. And since any such adventure needs an angry swarm of stinging insects, we have the Demon Hunter quest. With the Unleash the Colossus quest, you'll get regular tempo plays to inflict damage, followed by a reward that will make your future stings that much more deadly.

For those unfamiliar, Hearthstone quests are 1-mana spells that always start in your hand, and give you big rewards for completing their objectives. Demon Hunter's quest, Unleash the Colossus, challenges you to deal exactly two damage to an enemy on your turn, a whopping 15 times.

This may be an especially tricky proposition for Demon Hunter, whose hero power only deals one damage by default. But the full Demon Hunter quest package is built around giving you lots of options to deal exactly two damage, with a variety of new beasts to deliver the 2-damage stings. There's Gorishi Wasp that hits for two damage and gives you access to the Gorishi Stinger spell, which then delivers two damage twice more. Infestation, a new spell, also gives you Stingers. There's also the new Insect Claw weapon that gives you two charges of a two-damage strike, Gorishi Tunneler that acts as a two-for-one trigger of the quest by damaging both its target and the hero, and the 1-mana Silithid Grub with rush. Finally, while not a direct trigger for the quest, Silithid Queen synergizes well with the rest of the package by giving you big damage if you played a Beast the previous turn, thanks to its Kindred keyword.

So after delivering multiple stings against your opponent, you'll be rewarded with the Gorishi Colossus, a 5-mana 8/8 Beast that doubles your 2-damage attacks from that point on, for the rest of the game. That makes it very efficient at cutting down your opponent with lots of low-damage attacks, which Demon Hunter tends to excel at.

Hearthstone's Lost City of Un'goro expansion launches on July 8. Pre-purchases are available now. The regular bundle ($50) includes 60 packs, two random legendary cards, and a Spiritsinger Umbra card back. The Mega Bundle ($80) has 80 packs, 10 golden packs, one random Signature card, one random golden legendary card, four tavern tickets, and the Spiritsinger Umbra card back and Warlock hero skin. Finally, the Sequence Bundle ($60), available after purchasing the other two bundles, includes 10 more golden packs, 30 more card packs, and two random Signature legendary cards.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Hideo Kojima Doesn't Want His Company To Imitate Him After He's Gone
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hideo-kojima-doesnt-want-his-company-to-imitate-him-after-hes-gone/1100-6532356/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Legendary video game developer Hideo Kojima hasn't made a secret about being gravely ill during the COVID-19 pandemic, and he worried that he would never finish another project. Kojima is still thinking about his mortality even after his recovery. However, he doesn't believe that Kojima Productions would survive if he instructs his successors to keep making games exactly the way he does.

"I am not going to pass the baton to anyone," Kojima told British GQ. "I will rather crush the baton… [Laughs] I don't need to give 'Hideo Kojima' to anyone. If I pass the baton to my staff and tell them to make things the same way I do, the company will not succeed and will go out of business."

When asked to elaborate on his statement, Kojima explained that creators who are inspired by him "received my small fire" and aren't trying to be exactly like him. He's happy to have influenced so many, but not eager to see anyone try to copy him exactly.

Earlier this year, Kojima disclosed that he filled a USB stick full of his ideas for video games to be used after his death. He referred to it as his "will," and stated that he would rather Kojima Productions continue making new games and new ideas rather than simply repeating the ones he's already made.

Kojima's next game, Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, will be released on PlayStation 5 on June 26. His other upcoming titles include the Xbox-exclusive OD and the spy-action game Physint. Kojima is also involved with the A24 Death Stranding movie, and he has expressed interest in directing his own original film.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
